Memory Management Best Practices Guide

A comprehensive guide to manual memory management in Sacalon, covering patterns, pitfalls, and performance optimization techniques.

January 28, 2023
Core Team

Memory management is one of Sacalon's key strengths, offering developers fine-grained control over memory allocation while maintaining safety and performance. This comprehensive guide covers best practices, common patterns, and optimization techniques for effective memory management in Sacalon.


Understanding Sacalon's Memory Model


Sacalon provides a hybrid approach to memory management:


  • **Automatic Management**: For most common use cases
  • **Manual Control**: When you need precise control over allocation and deallocation
  • **Safety Guarantees**: Compile-time checks prevent common memory errors

    • Memory Ownership


    Sacalon uses an ownership system similar to Rust but with more flexibility:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    struct Buffer {

    data: *mut u8,

    size: usize,

    capacity: usize

    }


    impl Buffer {

    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {

    let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);

    return Buffer {

    data: data,

    size: 0,

    capacity: capacity

    };

    }


    func destroy(self) {

    deallocate(self.data);

    }

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Best Practices


    1. Use RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization)


    Always tie resource lifetime to object lifetime:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    struct FileHandler {

    file: *File,


    func new(filename: String) -> Result<FileHandler, Error> {

    let file = openFile(filename)?;

    return Ok(FileHandler { file: file });

    }


    func destroy(self) {

    closeFile(self.file);

    }

    }


    // Usage

    func processFile(filename: String) -> Result<(), Error> {

    let handler = FileHandler::new(filename)?;

    // File automatically closed when handler goes out of scope

    return Ok(());

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    2. Prefer Stack Allocation When Possible


    Stack allocation is faster and automatically managed:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Good: Stack allocated

    func processSmallArray() {

    let array: [Int; 100] = [0; 100];

    // Automatically cleaned up

    }


    // Use heap only when necessary

    func processLargeArray(size: usize) {

    let array = allocateArray<Int>(size);

    defer deallocate(array);

    // Process array

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    3. Use Smart Pointers for Shared Ownership


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    use std::memory::{Rc, Arc, Box};


    // Single ownership

    let data = Box::new(ExpensiveData::new());


    // Shared ownership (single-threaded)

    let shared_data = Rc::new(ExpensiveData::new());

    let reference1 = shared_data.clone();

    let reference2 = shared_data.clone();


    // Shared ownership (multi-threaded)

    let thread_safe_data = Arc::new(ExpensiveData::new());

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    4. Implement Custom Allocators for Performance-Critical Code


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    struct PoolAllocator {

    pool: *mut u8,

    size: usize,

    used: usize

    }


    impl PoolAllocator {

    func new(size: usize) -> PoolAllocator {

    let pool = allocate<u8>(size);

    return PoolAllocator {

    pool: pool,

    size: size,

    used: 0

    };

    }


    func allocate<T>(self, count: usize) -> *mut T {

    let needed = sizeof<T>() * count;

    if self.used + needed > self.size {

    panic("Pool allocator out of memory");

    }


    let ptr = self.pool + self.used as *mut T;

    self.used += needed;

    return ptr;

    }


    func reset(self) {

    self.used = 0;

    }

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Common Patterns


    1. Object Pools


    Reuse expensive objects to reduce allocation overhead:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    struct ObjectPool<T> {

    available: Vec<T>,

    create_fn: func() -> T

    }


    impl<T> ObjectPool<T> {

    func new(create_fn: func() -> T) -> ObjectPool<T> {

    return ObjectPool {

    available: Vec::new(),

    create_fn: create_fn

    };

    }


    func acquire(self) -> T {

    if self.available.isEmpty() {

    return (self.create_fn)();

    } else {

    return self.available.pop().unwrap();

    }

    }


    func release(self, obj: T) {

    self.available.push(obj);

    }

    }


    // Usage

    let pool = ObjectPool::new(|| ExpensiveObject::new());

    let obj = pool.acquire();

    // Use object

    pool.release(obj);

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    2. Memory-Mapped Files


    For large file processing:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    use std::memory::MemoryMap;


    func processLargeFile(filename: String) -> Result<(), Error> {

    let map = MemoryMap::open(filename)?;

    let data = map.asSlice<u8>();


    // Process data without loading entire file into memory

    for chunk in data.chunks(4096) {

    processChunk(chunk);

    }


    return Ok(());

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    3. Copy-on-Write (COW) Strings


    Optimize string operations:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    enum CowString {

    Borrowed(*const str),

    Owned(String)

    }


    impl CowString {

    func new(s: *const str) -> CowString {

    return CowString::Borrowed(s);

    }


    func toOwned(self) -> String {

    match self {

    Borrowed(s) => String::from(s),

    Owned(s) => s

    }

    }


    func makeOwned(self) {

    match self {

    Borrowed(s) => {

    self = CowString::Owned(String::from(s));

    },

    Owned(_) => {} // Already owned

    }

    }

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Performance Optimization Techniques


    1. Memory Layout Optimization


    Structure your data for cache efficiency:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Bad: Poor cache locality

    struct BadLayout {

    flag1: bool, // 1 byte + 7 bytes padding

    value1: i64, // 8 bytes

    flag2: bool, // 1 byte + 7 bytes padding

    value2: i64 // 8 bytes

    }


    // Good: Better cache locality

    struct GoodLayout {

    value1: i64, // 8 bytes

    value2: i64, // 8 bytes

    flag1: bool, // 1 byte

    flag2: bool // 1 byte + 6 bytes padding

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    2. Memory Pool Strategies


    Different strategies for different use cases:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Linear allocator for temporary allocations

    struct LinearAllocator {

    buffer: *mut u8,

    size: usize,

    offset: usize

    }


    // Stack allocator for LIFO allocations

    struct StackAllocator {

    buffer: *mut u8,

    size: usize,

    top: usize

    }


    // Free list allocator for general purpose

    struct FreeListAllocator {

    buffer: *mut u8,

    size: usize,

    free_blocks: Vec<Block>

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them


    1. Memory Leaks


    Always pair allocations with deallocations:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Bad: Potential memory leak

    func processData() {

    let data = allocate<u8>(1024);

    if someCondition() {

    return; // Memory leak!

    }

    deallocate(data);

    }


    // Good: Use RAII or defer

    func processData() {

    let data = allocate<u8>(1024);

    defer deallocate(data);


    if someCondition() {

    return; // Memory automatically freed

    }

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    2. Use After Free


    Sacalon's ownership system helps prevent this:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Compile-time error prevention

    func dangerousCode() {

    let data = Box::new(42);

    let ptr = data.asPtr();

    drop(data); // data is moved and freed

    // println(*ptr); // Compile error: use after free

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    3. Double Free


    Use smart pointers to prevent double free:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    // Bad: Manual management

    let ptr = allocate<i32>(1);

    deallocate(ptr);

    // deallocate(ptr); // Double free!


    // Good: Smart pointer

    let data = Box::new(42);

    // Automatically freed when data goes out of scope

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Profiling and Debugging


    Memory Profiling Tools


    Use Sacalon's built-in profiling tools:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    use std::profiler;


    func main() {

    profiler::startMemoryProfiling();


    // Your code here

    heavyMemoryOperation();


    let report = profiler::getMemoryReport();

    println("Peak memory usage: {} MB", report.peakUsage / 1024 / 1024);

    println("Total allocations: {}", report.totalAllocations);

    println("Memory leaks: {}", report.leaks.len());

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Debug Builds


    Enable memory debugging in debug builds:


    struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    #[cfg(debug)]

    use std::memory::debug;


    func allocateDebug<T>(count: usize) -> *mut T {

    let ptr = allocate<T>(count);

    debug::trackAllocation(ptr, sizeof<T>() * count);

    return ptr;

    }

    acalon
struct Buffer {
    data: *mut u8,
    size: usize,
    capacity: usize
}

impl Buffer {
    func new(capacity: usize) -> Buffer {
        let data = allocate<u8>(capacity);
        return Buffer {
            data: data,
            size: 0,
            capacity: capacity
        };
    }
    
    func destroy(self) {
        deallocate(self.data);
    }
}

    Conclusion


    Effective memory management in Sacalon requires understanding the language's ownership model, following best practices, and using the right tools for profiling and debugging. By applying these techniques, you can build high-performance applications that are both safe and efficient.


    Remember:

  • Use RAII patterns whenever possible
  • Prefer stack allocation for small, short-lived data
  • Use smart pointers for automatic memory management
  • Profile your applications to identify memory bottlenecks
  • Test thoroughly with memory debugging tools enabled

    • Happy coding with Sacalon!


    *The Core Team*
